result.value: Calrissian is a [CWL](https://www.commonwl.org) implementation designed to run inside a Kubernetes cluster. Its goal is to be highly efficient and scalable, taking advantage of high capacity clusters to run many steps in parallel.

Calrissian leverages [cwltool](https://github.com/common-workflow-language/cwltool) heavily and most conformance tests for CWL v1.0. Please see [conformance](conformance) for further details and processes.

When encountering a Kubernetes API exception, Calrissian uses a library to retry API calls with an exponential backoff. See the [tenacity documentation](https://tenacity.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html#waiting-before-retrying) for details.

## Installation

Calrissian is available at: [https://pypi.org/project/calrissian/](https://pypi.org/project/calrissian/)

Install it with:

```
pip install calrissian
```
Please see [examples](examples) for installation and setup instructions.
Note that for development you can just use [Hatch] directly as described below.

The main tool that is used for development is [Hatch]. It manages dependencies (in a virtualenv that is created on the fly) and is also the command runner.

So first, [install it][install Hatch]. Ideally in an isolated way with **`pipx install hatch`** (after [installing `pipx`]), or just `pip install hatch` as a more well-known way.

result.description:
## [v0.16.0] - 2023-11-23

### Changes

- Updated dependencies and python up to 3.10 (PR #161)
- New builds using github actions (PR #161)
- Updated badge for build status
result.name: v0.16.0

result.description:
## [v0.14.0] - 2023-06-19

### Added

- adds CWL GPU requirements supports (PR #153)
result.name: v0.14.0

result.description:
## [v0.13.0] - 2023-06-06

### Added

- adds an argument `--conf <conf_file_path>` that enables CLI arguments from a json file (PR #150)
- adds a default path for config file `~/.calrissian/default.json` (PR #150)

### Changed

- Updated cwltool to `3.1.20230201224320` and some other dependencies. (PR #142)
result.name: v0.13.0

result.description:
## [v0.12.0] - 2023-02-13

### Added

- adds an argument `--tool-logs-basepath <local_folder_path>` that enable the tool to fetch the pod logs by tool specified in the workflow (PR #139)
- returns proper exit code when the pod fails (PR #139)

### Changed

- contraints the pod to complete with a proper termination status or raise an exception. (PR #139)

## [v0.11.0] - 2022-11-10

### Added

- adds an argument `--pod-nodeselectors <yaml_file>` to add a node selector for computing pods
- add2 `--pod_serviceaccount` arg to set pods servicea account 

### Changed

- cwltool upgraded to current version 3.1 + all requirements
- Fixed faulty bytes in log stream (PR #137)

## Added
adds an argument --pod-env_vars <yaml_file> that allows passing environment variables to the submitted pods at runtime.

## Changed
cwltool upgraded to current version 3.0 + all requirements
result.name: 0.10.0 - Pod Environment Customization

result.description: - Uses [tenacity](https://tenacity.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) to retry Kubernetes API calls, designed for managed offerings where API may become unavailable during upgrades  #102
result.name: 0.9.0 - Kubernetes API Retries

result.description:
- Updates python base to 3.7 #99
- Updates cwltool to 1.0.20190621234233 and can run 1.1 conformance tests #94 
- Updates kubernetes python client to 10.0.1 #97 
- Replaces MultithreadedJobExecutor with ThreadPoolJobExecutor #99
result.name: 0.8.0 - Thread Pool Executor, update dependencies

result.description:
- Updates to use canonical location of CWL Conformance Tests #89 
- Ensures stdout/stderr redirection paths exist with an `initContainer` #93 
- Implements append_volume to support file literals #91
result.name: 0.7.0 - Conformance Improvements

result.description:
- Expands and updates documentation to describe cluster requirements, using with `kubectl` and how to run CWL conformance tests #72 
- Fixes issue blocking ROX volumes from correctly mounting on multiple pods #81 
- Improves test coverage #80
result.name: 0.6.0 - Cleanup docs, CWL conformance tests, Improved read-only storage support

result.description:
- Adds storage to usage reporting - #61
- Uses `emptyDir` for tmp directories - #62. `--tmpdir-prefix` usually not needed (see #65)
- Upgrades PyYAML in requirements.txt - #64
result.name: 0.5.0 - Storage usage reporting and tmp improvements

result.description:
- Adds command-line arguments to write stdout/stderr to files #57 
- Sends logs from individual CWL job pods to calrissian logging (stderr) #59 
- Allows trailing slashes in volume mounts #56
result.name: 0.4.0 - Logging Improvements

result.description:
- Simplify getting started in different openshift projects #54
- Docker image has a home directory and default user #55
result.name: 0.3.1 - Streamline Example Usage

result.description:
- Adds `--usage-report` option to record memory/cpu usage statistics to a JSON file
- Changes `--max-ram` to support [kubernetes memory suffixes](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/configuration/manage-compute-resources-container/#meaning-of-memory) (e.g. `--max-ram 1G`). **Omitting the suffix will now default to bytes**.
- Consult example openshift job YAML for changes
result.name: 0.3.0 - Usage Reporting

result.description: Adds an optional command-line argument, `--pod-labels <labels.yaml>` that applies labels from a YAML (or JSON) file to all Pods submitted.
result.name: 0.2.1 - Pod Labeling

result.description: - Adds a PodMonitor class that tracks outstanding pods and deletes them if calrissian is terminated or raises an internal exception
result.name: 0.2.0 - Cleanup on Termination

result.description:
- Updates CircleCI config to upload releases to PyPI
- Fixes issue where `calrissian --version` printed help instead of version
result.name: 0.1.1 - Versioning and CI publishing

result.description: Initial release with installer
result.name: 0.1.0 - Initial release

result.value:
Calrissian requires a [Kubernetes](https://kubernetes.io) or [Openshift](https://www.openshift.com)/[OKD](https://www.okd.io) cluster, configured to provision [PersistentVolumes](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/storage/persistent-volumes/) with the `ReadWriteMany` access mode. Kubernetes installers and cloud providers don't usually include this type of storage, so it may require additional configuration.

Calrissian has been tested with NFS using the [nfs-client-provisioner](https://github.com/kubernetes-incubator/external-storage/tree/master/nfs-client) and with GlusterFS using [OKD Containerized GlusterFS](https://docs.okd.io/3.11/install_config/persistent_storage/persistent_storage_glusterfs.html). Many cloud providers have an NFS offering, which integrates easily using the nfs-client-provisioner.

Calrissian is designed to issue tasks in parallel if they are independent, and thanks to Kubernetes, should be able to run very large parallel workloads.

When running `calrissian`, you must provide a limit the the number of CPU cores (`--max-cores`) and RAM megabytes (`--max-ram`) to use concurrently. Calrissian will use CWL [ResourceRequirements](https://www.commonwl.org/v1.0/CommandLineTool.html#ResourceRequirement) to track usage and stay within the limits provided. We highly recommend using accurate ResourceRequirements in your workloads, so that they can be scheduled efficiently and are less likely to be terminated or refused by the cluster.

`calrissian` parameters can be provided via a JSON configuration file either stored under `~/.calrissian/default.json` or provided via the `--conf` option.

Below an example of such a file:

```json
{
    "max_ram": "16G",
    "max_cores": "10",
    "outdir": "/calrissian",
    "tmpdir_prefix": "/calrissian/tmp"
}
```

```
hatch run test:test
```

Verbose: 

```
hatch run test:testv
```
